data.title: When error in script and "Open dominant script on Scene change" is checked, related scene shoud be opened
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Was avoiding to open this issue for a very long time, mostly because I don't feel like a lot of people would benefit from this, but it's coming back to me constantly, so here we go:
In general I'm not using script panel to much, it's quite confusing for me. As far as I know for people like me there is an option `Open dominant script on Scene change`, when this option is checked for 90% of time the script you are seeing is the script that is related to opened scene and this is cool.
The problem occurs in those remaining 10% of time. The most common case when this happens is simply at the time when there is an error in the script:
![scene_script_relation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/16733524/2e919490-4782-11e6-9c50-b4ee36c89c3b.png)
In this example the error is inside the script that is related to SplashNew.tscn scene, but what I'm seeing when I'm looking at tabs is "BaseBall.tscn" and this is confusing me regularly.  
It would be super nice if Godot could open scene that's linked to script in which error occur.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

Debug template is full and work sucessfull.

Compile with:
scons platform=android target=release_debug
gradlew build

in bin folder:
11.07.2016  10:39         9 657 862 android_debug.apk
11.07.2016  10:39         1 543 280 android_release.apk

Release templates is without Godot libs.

data.title: Avoid API changes in revisions (x.y.Z).
data.body:
Re: https://godotengine.org/article/maintenance-release-godot-2-0-4 -
"Added InputMap.get_actions()"
"Rename CanvasItem.edit_get() to edit_get_state()"

Whilst the former isn't such an issue, the latter could cause (albeit only minor) issues if the previous syntax/statement is removed altogether.

Perhaps such changes should either be reserved for minor versions (x.Y.z) or a warning added that the previous way of doing things is obsolete (and to be removed at the next minor version increase)?

data.title: Fix tree drawing the pressed stylebox in all buttons in the column
Scroll Container doesn't follow focus of elements inside it
data.body:
godot alpha 2.1 linux x32

Structure:
ScrollContainer
-- VboxContainer
----ItemEntry

When navigating through entries with keyboard, scroll container doesn't follow the focus and you can't see what item is selected. Also, you can't scroll through entries, unless you hover your mouse over the scroll bar or empty space in the list (which isn't how scrolling works, check any scrolling lists in your OS). 

What should happen: 
When you focus on entry that's partially or completely out of bounds of scroll container, it should set it's value to completely show the entry. If you scroll mouse with cursor in bounds of scroll container it should scroll. Pressing PageDown/PageUp should set scroll so only the last/first element is visible on top/bottom of the scroll container. 

At screenshot you can see how the topmost item in list has focus. If you press up, it switches focus to next element without moving the scroll. For controller friendly games it pretty much breaks the usability. 
![clearcolor16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10696955/16716169/c0afdcf4-46fd-11e6-9419-09cf3cc4e961.png)

[ScrollContainerBuggeh.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/357137/ScrollContainerBuggeh.tar.gz)
Project for testing. In scroll container, you can scroll through elements only when you hover empty area. Issue with focus is present in both ItemList and ScrollContainer

data.title: VisibilityEnabler2D still toggles particles after being disabled by code
data.body:
**Tested on Godot 2.0.3 and 2.0.4, Windows 10 64 bits**

**How it happened:**
In my game, pickups have particles on them. When the player picks them, I hide them and disable particle emission, because that way it won't "pop out" and I can make them respawn easily when the level restarts (which happens a lot).

To reduce CPU usage, I added VisibilityEnabler2D on pickups so their particles aren't simulated when out of view.
Problem: disabled pickup started to emit particles again when the player goes back the place where it was, because VisibilityEnabler2D activates them again.

Then, in addition to disable emission, I also turn off VisibilityEnabler2D with this code:

``` gdscript
get_node("VisibilityEnabler2D").set_enabler(VisibilityEnabler2D.ENABLER_PAUSE_PARTICLES, false)
```

However it doesn't works at all, the enabler continues to enable or disable particles.
It works if I disable the enabler from the inspector, but in code I see no change.

**Example project:**
Here is a test project in which  I disable the enabler from code:
[ParticlesEnabler.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/356128/ParticlesEnabler.zip)

Press right arrow to move the camera away from the particles. Notice it stops emitting, ignoring the `ENABLER_PAUSE_PARTICLES` setting.
(I also noticed a kind of margin, the camera has to be further away from the area)
You can also notice this when intentionally disabling particles: they will start to emit once in view.

**What was expected:**
1) VisibilityEnabler2D should work the same in code and inspector
2) Should pause particle simulation instead of changing emission

data.title: Support for control bone removal in Collada exporter
data.body:
This PR adds support for a feature in spec of the Collada exporter but was not avaliable. Prefixing 'ctrl' to any bone in an armature will now discard it during the export phase. As well as bones at the end of the tree, it can also discard control bones which lie between the root and the rest of  the armature by providing matrix compensation in the animation export. It doesn't remap vertex weights as of yet (though it could probably be added), but that is probably outside the scope of what this feature is meant to provide, specifically just the removal of redundant control bone helpers. I also replaced the matrix 'inverted' methods with 'inverted_safe' which should resolve some exporter crashes with zero bone scaling (the pre-existing workaround does not solve the issue).

Should be useful in optimizing more advanced and complex character rigs.

data.title: Open Godot's windows at a better position
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.0.4, Windows 10 64 bits:

When any Godot window opens (project manager, editor or games), it appears on the top-left of the screen, and if you happen to have your taskbar on top, the title bar appears under it.

![godot_window_under_taskbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/16714005/5f929650-46b7-11e6-8acb-a1b7f2de12f9.png)

There is a `game window placement` parameter, but 1) it is in editor settings, 2) it's only for games, 3) it doesn't affects the exported game.
So I fixed this in my game by directly writing this script in auto-load to center the window, so it won't annoy players:

``` gdscript
extends Node

func _ready():
    # Center window on screen
    var screen_size = OS.get_screen_size(OS.get_current_screen())
    var window_size = OS.get_window_size()
    var centered_pos = (screen_size - window_size) / 2
    OS.set_window_position(centered_pos)
    # Note: not tested on mobile platforms,
    # should do nothing in that case because it's fullscreen anyway
```

The window still blinkes on the top-left when it opens, but at least it is repositionned after.

But the project manager and editor still have this issue.
I would suggest they appear at the center of the screen, like Unity3D does with its project manager.
This could be a common feature between tools and games, like, have an option for how the window should be placed when it is created on PCs. Because resolutions vary, it could be specified as an anchor or ratios.

data.title: Expose drag and drop from filesystem to GDScript
data.body:
from 
https://godotengine.org/qa/5972/list-files-that-been-dragged-onto-games-window-their-directory

> I want to create a batch processing application in godot - that takes for input files that have been dragged and dropped by the user to the application window. Is that something that is possible to do in godot? I need to get that data and store it in an array

Other possible applications of this would be for plugins - being able to drag external files onto a godot plugin window.

data.title: Saving a tilemap also saves the tileset
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.0.3 and 2.0.4, Windows 10 64 bits

Sometimes when I save a tilemap, Godot also saves the tileset it is using, and as a side effect it produces unwanted diffs in Git.
I expected the editor  not to touch the tileset at all, because the tilemap is using it, it's not supposed to modify the tiles themselves.
This happens in my project for a while, but I never found how until now.

Here is a test project:
[TilemapSavesTileset.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/356028/TilemapSavesTileset.zip)
Open it, and save the scene. Notice Godot tries to save the tileset:
`Also saving modified external resource: res://tilesets/terrain_tileset2.tres`

data.title: LineEdit placeholder property now accepts translated strings.
data.body: Now you can use auto-translated strings  on the LineEdit placeholder text.

data.title: On import animation optimization doesn't work because of node renaming
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 8 - Bleeding Edge (454b210242ec15a9928324757f27989216bc5a59)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Okay, so a recent update (0db02f26b66ba4e3ac671607ba85fc794ae698fa) introduced some changes to the scene import, but one thing it broke was the running the animation optimizer on scenes as they're imported. The reason specifically for this breaking is because the update made it so that the AnimationPlayer node which is created automatically on scene import had its named changed to 'animations', whereas the method for method for preprocessing animation optimization search for a node with the default name 'AnimationPlayer'. This is obviously incredibly trivial to fix, and I would have already fixed it myself, but I wanted to know whether there was a reason for renaming the AnimationPlayer node, and whether it should be fixed by either reverting the name or have the optimizer method simply search for the node with a new name.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Import any Collada file with animation using the optimization flag.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Crash on saving script
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux Mint 18 x64
Godot 2.0.4 Stable (Linux 64) (download from site)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The editor randomly crashes when I save a script. **It happens only with old projects made in 2.0.3.** I tried 2.0.3 again and confirmed that the issue is only on 2.0.4. Also, it seems to only occur when using the hotkey (ctrl+s) to save the script. I haven't gotten it to crash when using the menu to save (File > Save). I made a new project in 2.0.4 and the issue went away, but when I tried moving over all my important files (*.tscn and *.png) the issue came back. The Control.tscn and Control.gd was made in 2.0.4 and all I did was try and edit and save Control.gd while having Control.tscn open, and it crashed again, even though I haven't even touched the old files from the 2.0.3 project, but before moving over the old files, it worked just fine. I think the issue has something to do with the *tscn files from 2.0.3.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open any project
2. Open any script
3. Make any small change (ex: add/remove newline)
4. Press ctrl-s to save script
5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 until it crashes (usually within 5 saves)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[game.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/355855/game.zip)

**Terminal Output** (No actual error messages appeared, but it crashed very time)
batmanasb@MintySuitcase ~ $ /home/batmanasb/MEGA/Godot/Godot2.0/Godot_v2.0.4_stable_x11.64
OPENING: /home/batmanasb/MEGA/Godot/Projects/Rogue Voyage/game (::home::batmanasb::MEGA::Godot::Projects::Rogue Voyage::game)
VBoxContainer: 136,100
batmanasb@MintySuitcase ~ $ bind toptions
TextureButton: 16,-4
Label: 289,63
HBoxContainer: 70,27
settings changed
^C
batmanasb@MintySuitcase ~ $ /home/batmanasb/MEGA/Godot/Godot2.0/Godot_v2.0.4_stable_x11.64
OPENING: /home/batmanasb/MEGA/Godot/Projects/Rogue Voyage/game (::home::batmanasb::MEGA::Godot::Projects::Rogue Voyage::game)
VBoxContainer: 136,100
bind toptions
batmanasb@MintySuitcase ~ $ settings changed
No completion
^C
batmanasb@MintySuitcase ~ $

data.title: 3D WorldEnvironment-CubeMap rotation
data.body:
It would be very nice feature if CubeMap (of 3D WorldEnvironment node) could have ability to become rotated.
This way it could be very easy to make a moving sky / stars / clouds effect just simply rotating the CubeMap along Y axis. (throught animationplayer / from code / timer ect...)

This should not make any difference for platforms other than Windows.

Fix #5596.
